misconceptions.name: Does not read the grade from user input
misconceptions.description: [Rubric: Reading numeric grade input, Points: 0/1] The program never asks the user to enter a numeric grade; instead, it reads coordinates for two points and uses a hard-coded grade value, so it does not satisfy the requirement to read a grade (0–100) from the keyboard.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it is acceptable either to reuse a distance-between-points template or to hard-code the grade instead of reading it from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for a numeric grade (0–100) using the Scanner and store that input in a variable, which is then used in the grading logic.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Grade is assigned with a literal int value (85) rather than read from input
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of code from another example (distance between points) and not updating it to match the grade-calculator problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate input with a single prompt like "Enter grade: " and read an int (or double) grade value using input.nextInt() or input.nextDouble(), then use that variable in your conditional logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no prompt for a grade and the only grade value is hard-coded as 85, which clearly violates the rubric requirement.

evidence.note: Program reads four doubles for point coordinates instead of a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing and incomplete Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.description: [Rubric: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B, Points: 0/1] The code only contains a single condition for 80–89 and does not handle the A range (90–100) at all, nor does it structure the logic as a complete grading scale for A and B.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that having just one dummy if-condition for the B range is sufficient for this part of the problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: There should be proper conditional checks that cover both A (90–100) and B (80–89), typically as part of an if/else-if chain, using the actual grade input variable.
symptoms: Only a single if-condition for grade >= 80 and grade < 90
No condition for grade >= 90
Condition is not connected to any real output or grading structure
misconceptions.root_cause: The student left in a fragment from another example and did not implement the full set of Boolean conditions required by the grading rubric.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use an if/else-if chain such as: if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } and ensure you cover the full A and B ranges using the actual user-provided grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Only one B-range condition appears, there is no A-range condition, and the comment labels it as a dummy example.

evidence.note: Only a B-range condition is present; A-range (90–100) is completely missing and there is no functional grading logic.

misconceptions.name: No default or else case for F grades

No logic that matches grades below 60 to an F

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: No letter-grade output based on ranges
misconceptions.description:
[Rubric: Mapping each range to correct letter output, Points: 0/1] The program never prints a letter grade (A–F) based on the numeric grade; instead it prints only the distance between two points, and the grading if-statement body is effectively empty.

Overall score: 0/5.
Overall feedback: The submission largely contains code for a different problem (distance between points) and only a non-functional grading stub. Re-implement the program so that it reads a grade, checks all ranges A–F, and prints the correct letter grade as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that leaving an empty if-statement for the grade and having some output (distance) is sufficient for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should output a line like "Letter grade: B" (or A, C, D, F) depending on the numeric grade, matching the ranges defined in the problem.
symptoms: No System.out.println or System.out.print that includes a letter grade
Only output is related to the distance between two points
The grade-related if-statement body performs no visible action
misconceptions.root_cause: The student reused unrelated example code and did not replace the output logic with the required grade-letter output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After computing which letter grade applies, use System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter); where letter is a char or String set by your if/else-if chain.
related_concepts: Combining computed results with user-friendly messages
Using conditionals to drive program output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no letter-grade print statement anywhere in the code, and the only output is the distance message.

double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The only user-visible output is the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
The grading condition does not produce any meaningful output such as a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between logical AND (`&&`) and bitwise AND (`&`)
misconceptions.description: In the rudimentary grade placeholder, the student uses the bitwise AND operator (`&`) for combining boolean comparison results within an 'if' statement, rather than the correct logical AND operator (`&&`). This is confirmed by the comment expressing confusion regarding 'one ampersand'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the single ampersand (`&`) is sufficient and standard for combining boolean conditions in Java code, unaware of the distinction between bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, logical short-circuiting AND is represented by `&&`. While `&` (bitwise AND) sometimes yields the correct boolean result, it operates differently by not short-circuiting the evaluation, which is inefficient and potentially dangerous if the right operand has side effects.
symptoms: Use of single '&' in conditional expressions.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the difference between logical and bitwise operators in Java, perhaps due to syntax similarity.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use `&&` for boolean logic in conditional statements. Remember that `&&` provides short-circuiting behavior, which is standard practice in Java.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly comments on the use of a single ampersand ('I need AND logic. One ampersand & should be enough.'), confirming the misunderstanding of which operator to use.

evidence.snippet:
// I need AND logic. One ampersand & should be enough.
        if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: The code uses '&' for boolean conjunction, coupled with a comment indicating the student's semantic confusion.

Single & used where && should be used in condition

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between logical && and bitwise & for Boolean AND
misconceptions.description: The student uses a single ampersand (&) in a Boolean condition and comments that one ampersand should be enough for AND logic, indicating a likely confusion between the logical AND (&&) and bitwise AND (&) operators in Java.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that using a single '&' is the correct or sufficient way to express logical AND in Java conditional statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, the typical operator for logical AND in conditions is &&, which short-circuits and does not evaluate the right-hand side if the left-hand side is false. The & operator can also be used with booleans but evaluates both operands and is primarily intended for bitwise operations on integral types.
symptoms: Comment explicitly stating that one ampersand & should be enough for AND logic
Use of a single & in a Boolean conditional expression
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely transfer from other languages or misunderstanding of Java's distinct logical (&&) and bitwise (&) operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use && for logical AND in if conditions (e.g., if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)). Reserve & for bitwise operations or special cases where evaluating both operands is intentional.
related_concepts: Logical vs bitwise operators in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses & in a Boolean condition and the adjacent comment explicitly references AND logic and a single ampersand, suggesting a misunderstanding rather than a deliberate choice.

evidence.snippet:
// I need AND logic. One ampersand & should be enough.
if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: The comment and the use of '&' in a Boolean condition indicate confusion between logical && and bitwise &.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using single bitwise 'AND' operator (&) instead of logical 'AND' operator (&&)
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator (`&`) in a conditional statement instead of the logical AND operator (`&&`). While this sometimes works for simple boolean comparisons, it is incorrect practice as it evaluates both sides regardless of the first result and can lead to unexpected behavior or performance issues (especially with method calls).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that a single ampersand (&) is the standard and sufficient logical AND operator in Java for conditional statements, possibly confusing it with the bitwise operator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, the logical AND operator is `&&` (short-circuiting). The single ampersand (`&`) is the bitwise AND operator, which is typically inappropriate for standard boolean logic in `if` statements.
symptoms: Use of '&' in boolean expression
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use the logical AND operator (`&&`) and the logical OR operator (`||`) when combining boolean expressions in `if` conditions. The single ampersand (`&`) performs a bitwise operation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence based on the explicit use of the single ampersand in the conditional statement and the accompanying comment explicitly stating the student's belief about needing 'One ampersand &'.

evidence.snippet:
// I need AND logic. One ampersand & should be enough.
        if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Uses single '&' operator and explicitly states the flawed belief in the comment.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Bitwise AND vs. Logical AND confusion
misconceptions.description: The student uses a single ampersand (&) for boolean logic instead of the logical AND operator (&&). While & can work in some contexts due to Java's type coercion, it's semantically incorrect for boolean expressions and shows a misunderstanding of Java operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: A single ampersand (&) can be used for boolean AND conditions in if statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Java uses && (logical AND) for boolean conditions in control structures. The & operator is a bitwise AND operator and should not be used for boolean logic.
symptoms: Incorrect operator choice in conditional statement
Potential unexpected behavior if operands are not pure booleans
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (&) and logical operators (&&). The student may be thinking of other languages or not fully understanding Java's operator set.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with && in boolean conditions: `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)`
